title: Explain please
body:
So basically I have had a positive win/loss ratio for the entire season so far. I was 1 game away from silver. at the time i was 59% win/loss. As what happens every season, out of nowhere comes the lose streaks and the the players that just seem worse in general than you had before coupled with the dcers every other game (this gripe is for another thread though). Now, even after this losing streak, i am still sitting on a positive win/loss ratio. Problem is, I'm one loss away from being demoted again and IF this happens, which it probably will, i will be WORSE off than where I was placed even though I still have won more games than I have lost. 

What kind of fucked up elo system is this? Can anyone explain how this makes any sense?

i take plenty of breaks, doesn't achieve anything. I'm trying to understand the logic behind it, not just to know "that's how it is".

What's with people down voting this. i'm asking a legitimate question. People are always on these forums telling others "if you win more than you lose you will climb". I've won more than I have lost and and the opposite has happened. Explain the logic behind it.

it's like saying 2 NBA teams. One has a 50-40 record and the other has a 51-39 record but is ranked lower than the 50-40.

I'll put it as simple as possible. Lets say out of 50 games you play in a row you consistently win 3 in a row then lose 1. Now after all of those games (remembering you have a decent win/loss ratio) you play and lose the next 20 games in a row.

This is how the MMR system works (without us seeing the MMR). MMR is what dictates who you actually play against. This is why in silver (my rank) I sometimes see plat players, because they have gone on large loss streaks tanking their MMR to silver level. This works the opposite, I went on a huge win streak to the end of last season while I was in silver 1  but I was playing with only platinum 3+ players every game. 

This is where LP gain/loss takes effect. When your MMR is fairly neutral you gain the middle amount of LP (I think average is 18). When you go on huge win streaks you start gaining a lot more (Up to 35 from what I have calculated/seen) but this works the opposite way. If you go on huge losing streaks you start losing a ton more LP per game. 

In the above senario I gave the win/loss for the first 50 games (due to no huge win/loss streaks) remains neutral but slightly raised (lets just say 23 per win - 18 per loss). Now imagine you tanked 20 losses in a row, you go from being fairly even to waaay outside the norm as the system thinks you should be winning and since you aren't it tanks you hard. For completeness sake you win your 21st game after 20 losses. But the damage is already done. You are now getting 15 per win and losing a huge 28 per loss.

The only way is to get back is by going on a huge winstreak or be consistent in your wins (takes ages to even out).

So even though you win way more games, since you lost more in a **row** you end up worse off. 

I think people would understand the system a lot more if Riot released our MMR to us so we can see what we are actually at. The problem with that though is that if you plateau after a huge win streak (like I did last season in Silver 1) even though I am playing only platinum players I started going even in my games. So yeah I was silver 1 but I never played against any silver players (couldn't get to gold) so I was just stuck in the  "platinum" level (1600mmr + according to the various sites around).

Thanks for the reply.

Firstly i want to point out that my MMR (according to an estimate on op.gg) isn't even that bad. I still gain 20+ points for a win. lose roughly 17-19 for a loss. the only thing i can think of that is the problem is promotion games. I have won a lot of promotion games which count towards win/loss ratio but you do not receive any kind of LP for them BUT you do lose LP when you lose promotion games (and lose the series).

about MMR, so basically the match making system is broken. the whole point of MMR and match making in general, especially in a TEAM game where you are matched with RANDOMS, is supposed to make the matches even. there is something inherently wrong with the system if it is continuously matching me with 'inferior" opponents and then also has the audacity to recognize that I'm "supposed to win" and then punish me further for losing. this may work better if it is a 1v1 game but it isn't. If my MMR has tanked due to a lose streak then it should be treating me as equal to those that it is now matching me with.

I don't believe any other game i play or have played in the past has allowed people to go backwards on the ladder if they have a positive w/l ratio. the timing of win/losses and streaks should be irrelevant. again, there's something inherently wrong with a system that over rewards/punishes for streaks ESPECIALLY in a team game with randoms.

I agree that MMR should be visible. I believe it was in the past (before i played this game). furthermore I think it should be the determinate for rank. Once you reach a certain MMR, then you rank up or rank down. Simple as that. They need to get rid of the possibility that someone in "gold" can be matched with silvers because of hidden MMR. If they have silver MMR, then they should be silver.

Also, promotion series (as pointed out at the start) are a huge problem. I understand that they have them as a guard or check against people climbing, but they just don't work. The fact that they now give you "free wins" in a series if you previously lost it shows that they realize there's something wrong. They should not count towards win/loss and therefore should have no bearing on MMR and LP. Better yet they should not exist.

Unfortunately this is the case in a world with imperfect people. Doesn't matter how good you are everyone has bad days and invariably those people end up playing against lower "skilled" players. 

The problems all come from the fact that our ranks are based entirely off win/loss. The best ranking system I have ever used (and it had itself many many problems) was halo 3. Even if your team played absolutely horribly and you lost the game. If you played above your own or at your own average level, the chances of you ranking down were lowered substantially.

Personally Riot should implement a system where if you play at your average or better and still lose a game the system should make you lose points still, but not as many. This can be easily implemented as they already have the backbone built in. The ranks you get for a champion after the game are based on your average and doesn't care about win/loss. I've played numerous games (support main) where I have gotten S+ and lost a game. 

So if in those cases I lost half the amount of points it wouldn't seem so bad. This encourages players to try and climb if they consistently play well but everyone else on their teams play badly. 

Also a pet peeve of mine. Riot seriously needs to implement the 2 top levels of champion mastery based entirely off getting first S then S+ ranks. This separates the actual "mains" from the "I played XX games and got max mastery". I am sick of playing with lvl 5 people only to find out they have no idea how to play a champion. /Sigh

*Edit* - On the point about inferior opponents. The system actually does do this but not for the reason people usually think. If you play a lot of your matches on red/purple side of the map you are actually playing with slightly "better" players by an average of 100MMR increase (The total of 5 people's MMR divided by 5). This is because the red/purple side of the map is considered a disadvantage. So when you play on blue side you legitimately are playing with the worse team as blue side has the better half of the map. I have watched this a lot and it is 100% true.
